title: Non-Rigid Structure from Locally-Rigid Motion

author: Jonathan Taylor, Microsoft Research, Cambridge, Microsoft Research
category: Top->Computer Science->Computer Vision->Stereo & Structure from Motion

Running our goal in this work is to reconstruct nonrigid scenes from a single video camera in very general settings where the scene and its motion are completely unknown where there are many independent motions and even connectivity changes through time.

All recent work on the problem.
This is its roots back to global methods for rigid structure for motion.
These methods jointly estimate the 3D coordinates of all points in all frames in a single optimization step, and were first popularized by the factorization algorithm.

This general approach has been immensely successful in reconstructing rigid scenes and represent a fairly radical departure from earlier work that focused on minimal configurations of points and views.
These methods have been extended to various classes of algorithms that can be applied to nonrigid scenes.
The first class segments have seen into multiple rigidly moving objects, each of which must contain enough tracks to resolve its 3D motion.

The second class assumes that all features lie on a single deforming body and work mostly well when deformations are small enough to allow standard rigid factorization to provide a good initial estimate of the bodies shape and motion.
